tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"This is for the director of music to use in worship"

tn.ref: A psalm of the sons of Korah
tn.text: "This is a psalm that the sons of Korah wrote"

tn.ref: Hear this, all you peoples; give ear, all you inhabitants
tn.text: These two phrases are parallel. Together they strengthen the command for all people to listen. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
This idiomatic expression means to use one's ears to listen. AT: "listen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

The writer speaks of people who are weak or insignificant in society as being low and of people who are important and powerful as being high. Together, the words "low" and "high" represent all people. AT: "both important people and unimportant people" (UDB) or "people of every social class" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
Together the words "rich" and "poor" refer to all people, regardless of wealth. AT: "all people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
Here the word "mouth" refers to the whole person who speaks. AT: "I will speak wise words" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: the meditation of my heart will be of understanding
tn.text: Here the word "heart" represents the mind and thoughts. The word "meditation" can be translated as a verb. AT: "the thoughts upon which I meditate will lead to understanding" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
The writer speaks of listening carefully to something as if it were bending one's ear towards the person who is speaking. AT: "listen carefully" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"as I play the harp"
The writer asks this question to emphasize that he has no reason to fear when bad things happen. AT: "I have no reason to fear ... heels." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"when evil things happen." Here the word "days" refers to general periods of time.

tn.ref: when iniquity surrounds me at my heels
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) the writer speaks of the evil desires of his enemies as if it were a predator ready to overtake him. AT: "when the iniquity of sinful men is ready to overcome me" or 2) the writer's enemies surround him as they commit their iniquity (UDB). AT: "when my enemies surround me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: those who trust in their wealth
tn.text: These people trust their wealth will keep them from having to suffer. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: about the amount of their riches
tn.text: a large amount of something

tn.ref: It is certain that no one
tn.text: "There is no way that any of them can" or AT: "No one can"

tn.ref: no one can redeem his brother or give God a ransom for him
tn.text: Both of these phrases express that a person cannot give God enough money to be able to avoid death. AT: "no one can pay money to God so that their brother will not die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: the redemption of one's life is costly
tn.text: The word "redemption" can be translated with a verb. AT: "it costs too much to redeem a person's life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: so that his body should not decay
tn.text: This refers to the body decomposing in the grave.
The writer speaks of experiencing something as if it were seeing that thing. AT: "he will die and his body will decay" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Wise men die; the fool and the brute alike perish
tn.text: The author refers to all people by referring to those who have the most and least wisdom. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
This means a person who is stupid or unintelligent.
"Their belief"

tn.ref: and the places where they live, to all generations
tn.text: The verb may be supplied from the previous phrase. AT: "and the places where they live will continue to all generations" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: they call their lands after their own names
tn.text: "they name their lands after themselves." This phrase expresses ownership. AT: "they own their own lands" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"But man, even if he has wealth"

tn.ref: This, their way, is their folly
tn.text: The writer speaks of the fate of fools as if it is the destination at the end of the path on which they walk. AT: "This is the fate of those who practice folly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"yet after they die"
The author continues to describe people who believe their wealth will save them.

The writer compares people who will all die to a flock of sheep. Just as sheep cannot escape when the butcher decides to slaughter them, so men will not escape when it is their time to die. (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "God has appointed them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

The writer speaks of men dying by personifying death as a shepherd who leads them into the grave. AT: "death will take them away as a shepherd leads away sheep to be slaughtered" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here the word "morning" is a metaphor that refers to a time when God will vindicate righteous people and save them from evil people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: their bodies will be consumed in Sheol
tn.text: The writer speaks of Sheol, the place of the dead, as if it were a person or animal. He speaks of the decay of dead bodies as if Sheol were eating them. AT: "their bodies will decompose in the grave" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: God will redeem my life from the power of Sheol
tn.text: The writer speaks of Sheol as if it were a person who has power over those who die. From the context, it is implied that this power refers to consuming the bodies of the dead. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
Here the word "life" refers to the whole person. AT: "God will redeem me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: the glory of his house increases
tn.text: The word "glory" here refers to wealth or riches. Possible meanings are 1) "when he gains more wealth in his house" or 2) "when his family becomes richer."
"he will take nothing with him to the grave"

tn.ref: his glory will not go down after him
tn.text: The phrase "go down" refers to when the man dies. AT: "his glory will not go along with him when he dies" or "he will not keep his reputation when he dies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

Here the word "soul" refers to the whole person. This phrase means that he considered himself to be happy and successful because of his riches. AT: "He congratulated himself" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: and men praise you when you live for yourself
tn.text: Here the writer offers a general statement about how people speak of other people who are successful according to worldly standards.
This phrase refers to living successfully according to worldly standards. AT: "do well for yourself" or "live successfully" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: he will go to the generation of his fathers
tn.text: "he will go to where his fathers' generation is." This is a euphemism that means that the rich man will die and join his ancestors in the grave. AT: "he will join his ancestors in the grave" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

tn.ref: they will never see the light again
tn.text: The word "they" refers to the rich man and his ancestors. The word "light" may refer to the sun or be a metaphor for life. AT: "they will never see the sun again" or "they will never live again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
